content: The "Border Security and Responsibility Act 2009" aims to protect Federal lands along the US-Mexico border from unauthorized immigration, smuggling, and border enforcement activities while ensuring necessary security operations are carried out. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This section defines key terms such as "Indian tribe," "Secretary," and "Secretary concerned." SEC. 4. BORDER PROTECTION STRATEGY. This section outlines the border protection strategy as part of the Border Security and Responsibility Act 2009. The Border Protection Strategy, to be developed by multiple Secretaries in consultation with various officials, must include a comparative analysis of operational control levels achievable through different security measures like fencing, barriers, and additional Border Patrol agents. The Border Protection Strategy will analyze the effectiveness of various security measures, including natural barriers, advanced technology, and cooperation with other agencies. The Border Protection Strategy includes analyzing border security methodologies, cooperation with Mexico and Canada, and removal of obstructive vegetation. Cost analysis includes land acquisition, construction, maintenance, and contractor costs over 25 years. The cost analysis for the Border Protection Strategy includes labor, material, maintenance, contractor, management, and overhead costs over 25 years. It also considers the impacts on wildlife, habitats, water quantity, quality, and hydrology on various lands along the border, as well as the costs of mitigating adverse effects. The comprehensive cost analysis for the Border Protection Strategy includes expenses for replacing severed wildlife migration corridors with protected ones of equivalent biological functionality, impacts on culture, safety, and quality of life for border residents, and fiscal investments in acquiring and managing lands for conservation purposes along the United States' borders. The curr_chunk discusses the management of land for conservation purposes in various jurisdictions including National Park System units, National Forest System land, Bureau of Land Management land, and tribal lands, among others. The curr_chunk discusses recommendations for strategic border security management, including cost-benefit analysis and protection of investments in public lands. Required training for Customs and Border Protection agents or other Federal personnel is also highlighted. The curr_chunk focuses on providing cultural resource training for Customs and Border Protection agents and other Federal personnel involved in border security infrastructure. The training aims to achieve border security objectives while minimizing adverse impacts on natural and cultural resources. Coordination with relevant tribal governments is emphasized to ensure the training aligns with agency missions. The curr_chunk highlights the adverse impact on natural and cultural resources from border security activities. SEC. 5. ACTIONS TO GAIN OPERATIONAL CONTROL OF THE INTERNATIONAL LAND BORDERS OF THE UNITED STATES. This section focuses on improving operational control of the border. The Secretary of Homeland Security must gain operational control of the international land borders of the United States, prioritizing the use of various border enforcement techniques. Consultation with relevant government agencies and stakeholders is required to minimize the impact on the environment and communities. The Secretary of Homeland Security must gain operational control of international land borders, prioritizing border enforcement techniques. States must minimize the impact on environment, culture, commerce, safety, and quality of life near proposed action sites. This subsection does not create or negate any rights of action, affect eminent domain laws, or waive other applicable laws. The Secretary is not required to install specific security measures if deemed unnecessary. The Secretary of Homeland Security must prioritize operational control of international land borders, considering the impact on environment, culture, commerce, safety, and quality of life. Construction of border infrastructure cannot begin until 90 days after submission. Prioritize operational control of international land borders, construction of border infrastructure cannot begin until 90 days after submission of the border protection strategy to Congress. SEC. 6. BORDERLANDS MONITORING AND MITIGATION. The Secretary, in consultation with various agencies, will develop a monitoring and mitigation plan to address ecological impacts of border security infrastructure along US international land borders. The plan includes measures to preserve wildlife migration corridors, habitats, and connectivity, and control invasive species. The Secretary may implement a mitigation plan on various lands near US international borders to address ecological impacts, including adapting to climate change, controlling invasive species, maintaining water functionality, incorporating adaptive management, and protecting cultural resources. The Secretary of Homeland Security may transfer funds to other Federal agencies for conservation activities on non-Federal lands and mitigation activities on Federal lands. Activities must be carried out in consultation with the landowner or entity responsible for land management. The Secretary of Homeland Security can transfer funds to other Federal agencies for conservation and mitigation activities on non-Federal and Federal lands. Funds can be used to develop and implement a mitigation plan required for border security infrastructure and activities.
